meanings.def: a piece of equipment for catching animals
examples: a fox with its leg in a trap
A trap was laid, with fresh bait.

meanings.def: a clever plan designed to trick somebody, either by capturing them or by making them do or say something that they did not mean to do or say
examples: She had set a trap for him and he had walked straight into it.

meanings.def: an unpleasant situation from which it is hard to escape
examples: the unemployment trap
Some women see marriage as a trap.

meanings.def: a light carriage with two wheels, pulled by a horse
examples: a pony and trap
Shut your trap! (= a rude way of telling somebody to be quiet)
to keep your trap shut (= to not tell a secret)

meanings.def: a cage from which a greyhound (= a type of dog) is let out at the start of a race
a small area filled with sand on a golf course
to make a trap for catching animals close suddenly
to try to trick somebody into doing or saying something; to succeed in this
to do/avoid doing something that is a mistake but that seems at first to be a good idea
examples: Parents often fall into the trap of trying to do everything for their children.
The movie avoids the trap of spending too much time explaining things.

idioms.def: to make a trap for catching animals close suddenly

idioms.idiom: to fall into/avoid the trap of doing something
idioms.def: to do/avoid doing something that is a mistake but that seems at first to be a good idea
examples: Parents often fall into the trap of trying to do everything for their children.
The movie avoids the trap of spending too much time explaining things.

related: to fall into/avoid the trap of doing something

meanings.def: to put somebody in a dangerous place that they cannot get out of
examples: be trapped Help! I'm trapped!
be trapped by something We became trapped by the rising floodwater.
be trapped + adv./prep. They were trapped in the burning building.

meanings.def: to keep somebody in a bad situation that they want to get out of but cannot
examples: be trapped + adv./prep. He was trapped in an unhappy marriage.
I feel trapped in my job.

meanings.def: to have part of your body, your clothing, etc. held in a place so tightly that you cannot remove it and it may be injured or damaged
examples: I trapped my coat in the car door.
The pain was caused by a trapped nerve.

meanings.def: to force somebody/something into a place or situation that they cannot escape from, especially in order to catch them
examples: The escaped prisoners were eventually trapped in an underground garage and recaptured.
Police believe the fingerprints could help trap the killer.

meanings.def: to catch an animal in a trap
examples: Raccoons used to be trapped for their fur.

meanings.def: to catch or keep something in a place and prevent it from escaping, especially so that you can use it
examples: Solar panels trap energy from the sun.
He felt he had been trapped into accepting the terms of the contract.
The police managed to trap him into revealing his true identity.
